title: Nooti
overview: An idea that went rogue. I created the application to learn more about push notifications but ended up creating a fully functional application. I published it to the Google Play Store to see what reaction I would gain from it.

outline.goal: Intended to be a learning project but ended up becoming a fully functional published application.
outline.scope: Scheduling and planning were at the core of Nooti, providing multiple tools for organising and managing todos.
outline.industry: Nooti falls under the productivity and tools category and could be used to improve your organisation as well.

challenges.title: Planning and scheduling
content: The user needed the ability to organise their todos in as many ways as possible. To name a few, you could: create folders, schedule the notification and have a pre-planned routine.

challenges.title: Ease of use
content: Using the app needed to be simple, that's why when the app is launched the first thing the user is greeted with is a big new button. There should not have been distractions, and the app needed to be intuitive.

challenges.title: Customisation
content: Since the app is mobile-driven, it needed offline capabilities. I used firebase as the source of truth, and once connectivity was established, the app starts to sync with all the other devices.

conclusion: Thinking back on the creation of Nooti made me realise the mistakes I made and what could have been done better. For starters, the app was very rudimentary in its functionality. A hobbyist could consider it acceptable for a pet-project, but it offered no real value, nor did it benefit the general public in any meaningful way. There were also some design inconsistencies, and it had subpar user experience.
Ultimately Nooti was removed from the Google Play Store due to a violation of the guidelines. The violation, you ask? Nooti's splash screen logo was too big.
Keeping all this in mind, I did learn a substantial amount from this project. Looking back and seeing all the mistakes I made proves my growth as a software developer.
